# Source: https://reactflow.dev/learn/advanced-use/testing

# Testing 

There are plenty of options to test a React application. If you want to test a React Flow application, we recommend to use [Cypress ![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)](https://www.cypress.io/) or [Playwright ![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)](https://playwright.dev/). React Flow needs to measure nodes in order to render edges and for that relies on rendering DOM elements.

## Using Cypress or Playwright[](#using-cypress-or-playwright) 

If you are using Cypress or Playwright no additional setup is needed. You can refer to the getting started guide for [Cypress here ![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)](https://docs.cypress.io/guides/getting-started/installing-cypress) and for [Playwright here ![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)](https://playwright.dev/docs/intro).

## Using Jest[](#using-jest) 

If you are using [Jest ![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)](https://jestjs.io/), you need to mock some features in order to be able to run your tests. You can do that by adding this file to your project. Calling `mockReactFlow()` in a `setupTests` file (or inside a `beforeEach`) will trigger the necessary overrides.

``` 
// To make sure that the tests are working, it's important that you are using
// this implementation of ResizeObserver and DOMMatrixReadOnly
class ResizeObserver 
 
  observe(target: Element)  as globalThis.ResizeObserverEntry], this);
  }
 
  unobserve() 
 
  disconnect() 
}
 
class DOMMatrixReadOnly 
}
 
// Only run the shim once when requested
let init = false;
 
export const mockReactFlow = () => ,
    },
    offsetWidth: ,
    },
  });
 
  (global.SVGElement as any).prototype.getBBox = () => ();
};
```

If you want to test mouse events with jest (for example inside your custom nodes), you need to disable `d3-drag` as it does not work outside of the browser:

``` 
<ReactFlow nodesDraggable= panOnDrag=  />
```
